I take refuge in Vairocana and the vajra buddhas of the ten directions;
I also pay homage to the author of the treatise, the future Buddha Maitreya.
Now I will explain the three collections of precepts; may all bodhisattvas listen together;
Precepts are like a great bright lamp, able to dispel the darkness of the long night;
Precepts are like a true precious mirror, illuminating all dharmas without exception;
Precepts are like a maá¹‡i jewel, raining down objects to aid the poor and destitute.
Departing from the world, quickly becoming a buddha, only this Dharma is supreme!
Therefore, all bodhisattvas should diligently uphold and maintain it.
All great beings!
These four pÄrÄjika dharmas are the bodhisattva-mÄá¹­á¹›kÄ, explained in unison.
If a bodhisattva, out of greed for profit, praises himself and disparages others, this is called the first pÄrÄjika offense.
If a bodhisattva, due to his own stinginess, does not give out of compassion to those in poverty and suffering who come seeking,
and does not teach the Dharma out of greed for hearing it, this is called the second pÄrÄjika offense.
If a bodhisattva, out of anger, speaks harshly and does not stop, but strikes with his hand, or with a stick or stone, causing injury and fear, and his hatred increases,
and the offender seeks to repent but he does not accept their repentance and holds a grudge without letting go, this is called the third pÄrÄjika offense.

If a bodhisattva slanders the bodhisattva canon, expounds counterfeit dharmas, and ardently establishes himself in counterfeit dharmas, whether he understands it himself or receives it from others, this is called the fourth pÄrÄjika offense.
All good people!
The four pÄrÄjika offenses have been explained.
If a bodhisattva commits any one of these offenses out of strong afflictions, he loses the bodhisattva precepts and should receive them again.
Now I ask all good people:
Is this pure or not?
Say it three times.
All good people!
Since there is silence, this matter is to be regarded as pure.
It should be upheld like this!
All good people!
These many duá¹£ká¹›tas of bodhisattvas are the bodhisattva mÄá¹­á¹›kÄ, explained in combination.

If a bodhisattva, abiding in the precepts of discipline, during a single day and night, whether the Buddha is in the world or at the Buddha's stupa, or the Dharma, or the scriptures, or the bodhisattva sutra canon, or the bodhisattva vinaya canon, or the bhiká¹£u saá¹…gha, or the great bodhisattva assembly in the worlds of the ten directions;

If he does not make offerings, not even a little, not even a single prostration, not even a single verse praising the merits of the Three Jewels, not even able to think pure thoughts for a single moment, this is called committing many offenses;
If he is not respectful, or negligent, or lazy in his offenses, this is an offense that arises from defilement;
If he forgets or errs, the offense does not arise from defilement.
There is no offense if:

A bodhisattva who has entered the stage of pure mind, like a bhiká¹£u who has attained unshakable faith, always makes offerings to the Three Jewels of the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹…gha as a matter of course.
If a bodhisattva is greedy and insatiable, and is attached to wealth and possessions, this is called committing many offenses, and this offense is defiled.
There is no offense if:
In order to eliminate them, one generates the desire and skillful means to embrace and counteract them;
The intense afflictions arise again and again.
If a bodhisattva sees an elder with virtue who should be respected and who is of the same Dharma,
out of arrogance and anger, does not give rise to respect, does not yield his seat,
and does not respond to greetings or requests for the Dharma, this is called committing many offenses, and this offense is defiled.
If one is lazy or has a neutral mind, or if one commits the offense out of forgetfulness, it is not a defiled offense.
There is no offense if:
one is seriously ill, or one's mind is disturbed, or one is sleeping and thinks one is awake, and one does not respond to greetings or requests for the Dharma, this is called no offense.
If the elder is expounding the Dharma or engaging in definitive discussions;
Whether speaking the Dharma oneself, listening to the Dharma, or engaging in self-determination and discussion;
Whether in an assembly speaking the Dharma or in an assembly engaging in determination and discussion, not bowing is not an offense.
If one is protecting the mind of the speaker;
If one is using skillful means to cause them to be tamed, to abandon unwholesomeness and cultivate wholesome dharmas;
If one is protecting the rules of the Saá¹ƒgha;
If one is protecting the intentions of many people.

If a bodhisattva, when a donor comes to invite them, whether to their own home, to the temple, or to another's home, and offers them clothing, food, and various necessities, the bodhisattva, out of anger or arrogance, does not accept or go, this is called committing many offenses, and this offense arises out of defilement.
Not an offense:
If one is sick, if one is powerless, if one is insane;
If one is far away, if the road is dangerous;
If one knows that not accepting will cause them to be tamed, to abandon evil and abide in goodness;
If one has already accepted an invitation;
If one cultivates wholesome dharmas and does not wish to temporarily abandon them, in order to hear the unprecedented Dharma, the meaning of benefit, and definitive discussions;
If one knows that the request is for the sake of deception and vexation;
If one protects many people's feelings of resentment;
If one protects the rules of the Saá¹ƒgha.
If a bodhisattva, a donor offers gold, silver, pearls, maá¹‡i jewels, and various precious objects to the bodhisattva;
If the bodhisattva, out of anger or arrogance, refuses and does not accept, this is called committing many offenses, and this offense arises out of defilement.
Because it abandons sentient beings.
If one is lazy and negligent, the offense arises out of non-defilement.
There is no offense if:
one is insane;

if one knows that after accepting [the offering], one will definitely give rise to attachment;ğŸ”½if one knows that after accepting, the donor will give rise to regret;ğŸ”½if one knows that after accepting, the donor will give rise to confusion;
if one knows that after accepting, the donor will become impoverished and distressed;
If one knows that an object belongs to the Three Jewels,
if one knows that an object is obtained through theft,
if one knows that accepting it will lead to much suffering, such as being killed, bound, exiled, punished, having one's wealth confiscated, or being scolded.
If sentient beings come to a bodhisattva and wish to hear the Dharma,
if the bodhisattva, out of anger, resentment, and jealousy, does not speak for them, this is called committing an offense of wrongdoing. This offense is defiled.
If it is due to laziness and indolence, the offense is not defiled.
There is no offense if:
the non-Buddhist is seeking to find fault;
one is gravely ill or insane;
one knows that not speaking will lead to their discipline;
one has not yet mastered the Dharma that is being practiced;
one knows that the person in front does not have respect or obedience;
their deportment is not proper;
if they are of dull faculties and would become frightened upon hearing the profound and wondrous Dharma;
if one knows that upon hearing it, they would increase their wrong views;
If they know and hear it, they slander and fall back;
If they hear it, they tell evil people.

If a bodhisattva, with a mind of anger and resentment towards evil and immoral beings, either abandons them himself or prevents others from abandoning them and does not teach and transform them, this is called committing a fault that is a transgression, and this transgression arises from defilement.
If it is due to laziness and negligence, or if it is due to forgetting and preventing others, the transgression arises from non-defilement.
Why is it so?
Because the bodhisattva's compassionate mind towards evil people is deeper than towards good people.
There is no offense if
one is insane;
if one knows that by not speaking, one will be able to subdue them, as explained above;
if one is protecting the minds of others;
if one is protecting the rules of the Saá¹ƒgha.

If a bodhisattva, within the PrÄtimoká¹£a of the TathÄgatas, establishes the prohibition of offenses in order to protect beings, so that non-believers may believe and believers may increase, he should study together with the Å›rÄvakas.
Why is it so?
As for the Å›rÄvakas, they liberate themselves and do not abandon protecting others, causing the unbelieving to believe;
causing the faithful to increase in learning and precepts, let alone the ultimate liberation of the bodhisattvas.

Moreover, the prohibitions and offenses, abiding in little benefit, little practice, and little skillful means, were established by the World-Honored One for the Å›rÄvakas, but the bodhisattvas do not train in these precepts.
Why is it so?

The Å›rÄvakas liberate themselves and abandon others, and should abide in little benefit, little practice, and little skillful means, but the bodhisattvas liberate themselves and others, and should not abide in little benefit, little practice, and little skillful means.

For the sake of sentient beings, the bodhisattvas may request hundreds of thousands of robes from non-relatives, brahmins, and householders, and accept them if they are offered freely, considering whether the donors are able to give or not, and accept according to their offerings.
As with robes, so it is with alms bowls.
As with robes and alms bowls, so it is with requesting yarn from oneself and having a non-relative weaver weave it;
For the sake of sentient beings, one may accumulate silk bedding and sitting mats, up to hundreds of thousands.
Up to gold and silver, hundreds of thousands, one may also accept them.
Such are the prohibitions for Å›rÄvakas who abide in little benefit, little activity, and little skillful means, but bodhisattvas do not abide in them.

The bodhisattva precepts are for all sentient beings. If one abides in little benefit, little activity, and little skillful means with a mind of resentment, this is called committing many offenses, and this offense arises from defilement.
If one is lazy and negligent, abiding in little benefit, little activity, and little skillful means, the offense does not arise from defilement.

If a bodhisattva is deceitful in body and speech, shows off, slanders, or seeks profit through profit, abiding in wrong livelihood with a shameless mind, unable to let go, this is called committing many offenses, and this offense arises from defilement.
There is no offense if:
If one gives rise to desire and expedient means to sever them, the afflictions increase and arise again and again.

If a bodhisattva is agitated and does not enjoy tranquility, speaks loudly, plays, and makes others happy and joyful, using this as a cause, this is called committing many offenses. This offense arises from defilement.
If it is done out of forgetfulness, it does not arise from defilement.
There is no offense if:
In order to sever them, one gives rise to desire and expedient means, as explained above.
Moreover, there is no offense if:
In order to stop others' resentment and hatred;
In order to dispel others' sorrow and worry;
If others enjoy playing, in order to attract them, to sever their [afflictions], to protect them;
If others suspect the bodhisattva, resent him, turn against him, and he smiles and plays to show the purity of his mind.
If a bodhisattva has such views and speaks thus, saying:
'A bodhisattva should not enjoy nirvÄá¹‡a, should turn away from nirvÄá¹‡a;
One should not fear afflictions, nor should one be completely disgusted with them.
Why is this?
Bodhisattvas should undergo birth and death for a long time over three asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas, seeking great enlightenment.
Those who speak like this are said to commit many offenses, and these offenses arise out of defilement.
Why is this?

The Å›rÄvakas' deep delight in nirvÄá¹‡a and fear and disgust with afflictions are not even a hundredth, a thousandth, or a ten-thousandth as much as the bodhisattvas' deep delight in nirvÄá¹‡a and fear and disgust with afflictions.
This is because the Å›rÄvakas only benefit themselves, while the bodhisattvas are not like this, benefiting all beings.
Their practice does not arise from a defiled mind, and surpasses the arhats;
They accomplish the contaminated [path] and are free from all afflictions.
If a bodhisattva does not guard against words of disbelief, does not guard against slander and criticism, and also does not eliminate them,
If they have real faults and do not eliminate them, this is called committing many offenses, and this offense arises out of defilement.
If there is no real fault or evil that is not eliminated, it is not a defiled offense.
Not committing an offense means:
If non-Buddhists slander and other evil people;
If one goes forth, begs for food, and cultivates wholesome causes and conditions, giving rise to others' criticism;
If the other person is angry, insane, or slanders.
If a bodhisattva, observing sentient beings who should be benefited by harsh words, uses skillful means;
If he does not do it out of fear of causing them distress, it is called committing many offenses, and this offense is not defiled.
Not committing an offense means:
Observing that they have little benefit in the present but much distress.

If a bodhisattva, when scolded, retorts; when angry, returns anger; when struck, strikes in return; when reviled, reviles in return, it is called committing many offenses, and this offense is defiled.

If a bodhisattva offends others or, even if not offending, causes others to doubt, he should immediately repent and apologize. If he is resentful, contemptuous, or does not repent in accordance with the Dharma, this is called committing a fault that is a transgression, and it is a defiled offense. If it is due to laziness and indolence, it is not a defiled offense.
There is no offense if
he uses skillful means to subdue them;
if they want him to do impure acts before accepting his apology, there is no offense in not apologizing;
if he knows that person's nature is to quarrel and that repenting will increase their anger;
if he knows that person is harmonious and forbearing, without a resentful mind, and fears they will be embarrassed, there is no offense in not apologizing.

If a bodhisattva, when others come to offend him and repent in accordance with the Dharma, out of a resentful mind wishes to trouble them and does not accept their repentance, this is called committing a fault that is a transgression, and it is a defiled offense.
If one does not accept the apology due to resentment, it is a transgression but not a defiled offense.
There is no offense if:
one uses skillful means to subdue the other, as explained before.
If the other does not repent in accordance with the Dharma, and one's mind is not at peace, and one does not accept their apology, there is no offense.
If a bodhisattva gives rise to resentment towards others and holds onto it without letting go, it is called committing many offenses, and this offense arises from defilement.
There is no offense if:
one gives rise to the desire to eliminate it and uses skillful means, as explained before.
If a bodhisattva, out of greed for service, keeps and raises followers, it is called committing many offenses, and this offense arises from defilement.
There is no offense if:
one keeps them without greed.
If a bodhisattva is lazy, indulges in sleep, and does not know moderation at inappropriate times, it is called committing many offenses, and this offense arises from defilement.
There is no offense if:
If one is sick, if one is powerless, if one is exhausted from a long journey;
If one gives rise to the desire to cut them off, and makes efforts as explained above.
If a bodhisattva, with a defiled mind, discusses worldly matters for a long time, this is called committing many offenses, and this offense arises from defilement.
If one forgets and discusses for a long time, the offense does not arise from defilement.
There is no offense if:
Seeing others gather to talk, in order to protect their minds, one listens for a short while;
Or if one briefly answers a question about something one has never heard before.

If a bodhisattva, wishing to seek a concentrated mind, dislikes, is resentful, or arrogant, and does not accept the teacher's instructions, this is called committing many offenses, and this offense arises from defilement.
If one is lazy and negligent, the offense does not arise from defilement.
There is no offense if:
One is sick, or powerless;
If one knows that person speaks in a distorted manner;
If one is self-sufficient in learning and ability;
If one has already received the Dharma.
If a bodhisattva gives rise to the five hindrances and does not awaken to them, it is called committing many offenses, and this offense is defiled.
There is no offense if:
in order to eliminate them, one gives rise to the desire for skillful means, as explained above.
If a bodhisattva sees the enjoyment of meditation as a merit, it is called committing many offenses, and this offense is defiled.
There is no offense if:
in order to eliminate them, one gives rise to the desire for skillful means, as explained above.
If a bodhisattva sees in this way and speaks in this way:
'A bodhisattva should not listen to the sÅ«tras and teachings of the Å›rÄvakas, should not accept them, and should not study them.
What use do bodhisattvas have for the teachings of the Å›rÄvakas?'
This is called committing many offenses, and this offense is defiled.
Why is it so?
Bodhisattvas should even listen to the heterodox teachings of non-Buddhists, let alone the words of the Buddha.
There is no offense if:
exclusively studying the bodhisattva canon, one has not yet been able to master it.

If a bodhisattva does not make effort in the bodhisattva canon, abandons it and does not study it, and instead practices the sÅ«tras of the Å›rÄvakas exclusively, this is called committing many offenses, and this offense is not defiled.

If a bodhisattva abandons what is spoken by the Buddha and does not study it, and instead practices the heretical treatises and worldly scriptures of non-Buddhists, this is called committing many offenses, and this offense is defiled.
There is no offense if:
one is very intelligent and can quickly accept and study;
if one has studied for a long time and does not forget;
if one contemplates and knows the meaning;
if one fully observes the Buddha's teachings and attains unshakable wisdom;
if one studies the Buddha's sÅ«tras for two parts of the day and non-Buddhist scriptures for one part;
this is called not an offense.

If a bodhisattva is skilled in worldly scriptures and the heretical treatises of non-Buddhists, and does not abandon them with love, not regarding them as poison, this is called committing many offenses, and this offense is defiled.
If a bodhisattva, having heard the profound meaning of the bodhisattva canon, the true meaning, and the immeasurable spiritual powers of the buddhas and bodhisattvas, slanders and rejects it, saying:
'It is not beneficial, it is not spoken by the TathÄgata, and it also cannot bring peace and happiness to sentient beings,'
this is called committing many offenses, and this offense arises from defilement.
Either because one's own mind is not in proper contemplation, one slanders it, or because one follows others, one slanders it.
This bodhisattva hears the foremost profound meaning and does not give rise to an understanding mind.
This bodhisattva should give rise to a mind of faith and a mind free from flattery and deceit, and practice in this way:
'I am greatly at fault, blind and lacking the eye of wisdom;
The TathÄgata's wisdom eye speaks in accordance with this;
The TathÄgata's remaining teachings, how can I give rise to slander?'
This bodhisattva places himself in a position of ignorance.
In this way, the TathÄgata's presently known and seen Dharma, correct contemplation, and correct orientation are not offenses, and are not slander due to misunderstanding.
If a bodhisattva, with a mind of greed and anger, praises oneself and denigrates others, this is called committing many offenses, and this offense is defiled.
There is no offense if:
if one is denigrating non-Buddhists and extolling the Buddha's teachings;
if one is using skillful means to subdue them, as explained above.
Another case of no offense is:
causing those who do not believe to believe, and those who believe to increase in faith.

If a bodhisattva, hearing a place where the Dharma is being taught or a place where the definitive doctrine is being discussed, with a mind of arrogance or hatred, does not go to listen, this is called committing many offenses, and this offense is defiled.
If one is lazy and negligent, the offense is not defiled.
There is no offense if:
one does not understand, one is sick, one is powerless, they are teaching the Dharma in a distorted way, or one is protecting the mind of the teacher;
if one has heard it many times, has already memorized it, and already knows the meaning;
If one has much learning, or upholds what one has heard, or practices as taught;
If one cultivates meditation and does not wish to temporarily abandon it;
If one has dull faculties, finds it difficult to awaken, difficult to accept, and difficult to uphold;
Not going is not an offense.

If a bodhisattva despises those who expound the Dharma, does not give rise to respect, ridicules and slanders them, but only clings to the words and does not rely on the true meaning, this is called committing many offenses, and this offense arises out of defilement.
If a bodhisattva, abiding in the precepts of discipline, sees beings doing something, and with a mind of anger and resentment does not engage in the same activities as them, namely:
Considering various matters, whether traveling, engaging in lawful business, farming, raising cattle, resolving disputes, auspicious gatherings, or meritorious deeds.
Not engaging in the same activities as them is called committing many offenses, and this offense arises out of defilement.
If one is lazy and negligent, the offense does not arise out of defilement.
There is no offense if:
if sick, or if lacking strength;
if they are able to take care of themselves, if they have many companions, if what they are doing is not in accordance with the Dharma and principles;
if using skillful means to subdue them, as explained above;
if previously giving one's word to others, if they have enemies;
if cultivating wholesome actions oneself and not wishing to temporarily abandon them, if one's nature is dull, if protecting the minds of many people, if protecting the rules of the Saá¹…gha;
not being with them is all not an offense.
If a bodhisattva, seeing a weak patient, with a hateful mind, does not go to attend to them, it is called committing many offenses, and this offense arises out of defilement.
If lazy, the offense arises out of non-defilement.
The non-offenses are:
if oneself sick, if lacking strength, if instructing those with strength to comply with the sick person;
if knowing that person has their own relatives, if they have the ability to take care of themselves;
if the illness frequently occurs, if it is a chronic illness;
If one is cultivating superior karma and does not wish to temporarily abandon it;
If one is dull-witted, difficult to awaken, difficult to accept, difficult to uphold, and difficult to abide in the middle;
If one first attends to their illness.
As with illness, so it is with extreme suffering.

If a bodhisattva, seeing sentient beings creating evil karma in this world and the next, out of resentment does not give proper instruction, this is called committing many offenses, and this offense arises out of defilement.
There is no offense if:
If one is oneself without knowledge, if one is powerless, if one has someone with power speak;
If they themselves have power, if they themselves have good spiritual friends;
If by skillful means one causes them to be subdued, as explained above;
If one gives proper instruction, but they hate oneself;
If they speak evil words, if they misunderstand, if they have no affection or respect, or if their nature is stubborn and unruly.
If a bodhisattva, having received kindness from others, with a resentful mind does not repay it, whether equally or more, this is called committing many offenses, and this offense is defiled.
If it is due to laziness and indolence, the offense is not defiled.
There is no offense if:
one is making an effort but lacks the ability, or if one uses skillful means to subdue the other person, as explained before;
or if one wishes to repay the kindness but the other person does not accept it.

If a bodhisattva, seeing sentient beings with difficulties related to relatives or wealth, with a resentful mind does not help them to resolve their worries and distress, this is called committing many offenses, and this offense is defiled.
If it is due to laziness and indolence, the offense is not defiled.
There is no offense if:
as explained in the section on not participating in the same activities.
If a bodhisattva, when someone asks for food and drink or clothing, is unable to give it due to an angry and resentful mind, this is called committing many offenses, and this offense is defiled.
If it is due to laziness and indolence, the offense is not defiled.
There is no offense if:
one does not have it oneself; one seeks improper things; the things are not beneficial to the other;
if one uses skillful means to subdue the other, as explained above;
if the other has violated the king's law and one protects the king's intention;
if one protects the rules of the Saá¹…gha.

If a bodhisattva, having accepted a group of followers, due to an angry and resentful mind, does not instruct them properly, and is not able to seek clothing, food, bedding, medicine, and dwellings from brahmins and householders in a timely manner to provide for them, this is called committing many offenses, and this offense is defiled.
If it is due to laziness, indolence, or negligence, the offense is not defiled.
There is no offense if:
If one uses skillful means to subdue them, as explained above;
If one is protecting the monastic rules, if one is sick, if one is powerless, if one instructs those with power;
If they have power, many acquaintances, and great virtue, and seek the requisites themselves;
If they have received teachings before and already know the Dharma by themselves;
If non-Buddhists steal the Dharma and are unable to be subdued.
If a bodhisattva, with a mind of resentment, does not follow others, it is called committing many offenses, and this offense arises from defilement.
If one is lazy and negligent, the offense arises from non-defilement.
There is no offense if:
If they want to do something that is not in accordance with the Dharma;
If one is sick, powerless, or protecting the monastic rules;
If they, although in accordance with the Dharma, can cause many people to engage in non-Dharma activities;
If it is for subduing non-Buddhists, or if one uses skillful means to subdue them.
If a bodhisattva, knowing that other sentient beings have real virtues, out of a resentful mind does not speak of them to others, nor praises them;
if there are those who praise, does not exclaim 'Excellent!'
This is called committing many offenses, and this offense arises out of defilement.
If out of laziness, negligence, or heedlessness one commits an offense, it arises out of non-defilement.
There is no offense if:
knowing that person has few desires, in order to protect their mind;
if sick, or lacking strength;
if using skillful means to subdue them;
if protecting the rules of the Saá¹ƒgha;
if in order to prevent that person from giving rise to afflictions, giving rise to excessive joy, giving rise to arrogance, or giving rise to non-benefit, in order to avoid these problems;
if real virtues seem to be not virtues;
if real good speech seems not to be real speech;
if in order to subdue non-Buddhist wrong views;
if waiting for the speech to be finished.
If a bodhisattva, seeing a sentient being who should be scolded, subdued, or punished, out of a defiled mind does not scold them,
if scolding them, does not subdue them,
if subduing them, does not punish them,
this is called committing many offenses, and this offense arises out of defilement.
If out of laziness, negligence, or indulgence, one commits an offense, it arises out of non-defilement.
There is no offense if:
they are incurable, cannot be spoken to, difficult to teach, and often give rise to resentment;
if observing the time;
if fearing that because of them disputes, disagreements, or lawsuits will arise;
if there is a dispute in the Saá¹…gha or if the Saá¹…gha will be split;
if they are not deceitful, have a sense of shame and remorse, and gradually reform themselves.
If a bodhisattva, having attained various spiritual powers, should frighten those who should be frightened,
should guide those who should be guided,
in order to make sentient beings consume the offerings of faith.
If one does not frighten them with spiritual powers, lead and guide them, this is called committing many offenses. This offense is not defiled.
Not an offense:
If those beings give rise to attachment again, if non-Buddhists slander the sages, and if they attain wrong views, all are not offenses.
If they go crazy or if their suffering increases.
All good people!
The many duá¹£ká¹›tas have been explained. If a bodhisattva commits any one of these dharmas, he should perform the duá¹£ká¹›ta repentance.
If he does not repent, it will obstruct the bodhisattva precepts.
Now I ask all good people:
Is it pure in this matter?
Say it three times.
All good people!
Since it is pure in this matter, and you remain silent, this matter is thus upheld.
All good people!

I have already explained the four pÄrÄjika offenses of bodhisattvas and the many duá¹£ká¹›tas. This is the Vinaya taught in combination by Maitreya, the future Buddha, and MaudgalyÄyana. The precepts of restraining from wrongdoing, the precepts of accumulating wholesome dharmas, and the precepts of benefiting sentient beings.
These precepts are able to give rise to bodhisattva practices and accomplish the path of bodhisattvas.
All great beings!
Those who wish to arouse the mind and seek supreme, perfect enlightenment should uphold them well.

If one upholds them, one will not give rise to the thought that the semblance Dharma is the extinction of the Dharma, and will be able to make the true meaning of the semblance Dharma flourish, and will be able to prevent the true Dharma from ever being extinguished;
One's mind will attain correct abiding and will accomplish the Buddha's teachings by oneself;
One will be able to teach and transform sentient beings without ever feeling weary;
One's wholesome actions will be perfected and one will quickly accomplish the Buddha's path!
Bodhisattva PrÄtimoká¹£a
